fields.descriptive_line: Handwritten letter with envelope to Anne Hale from her cousin Esther sharp, written in Weymouth in 1858
fields.physical_description:
A single sheet letter on cream paper written in black ink, in a small battered white envelope addressed to Miss Hale, 11 Angell Terrace, Brixton, Surrey.
[envelopes] A small cream envelope addressed to Miss Hale, 11 Angell Terrace, Brixton, Surrey.
[letters (correspondence)] A single sheet letter on cream paper written in black ink folded down the centre in half and then into thirds in order to fit into the envelope.
fields.dimensions:
[envelopes] Width: 11.7 cm, Height: 6.9 cm
[letters (correspondence)] Width: 9.6 cm, Height: 15.8 cm
fields.marks:
[envelopes] 'Weymouth DE20 58 / SZ London DE21 58'  Miss Hale
11 Angell Terrace
Brixton
Surrey
[letters (correspondence)] Weymouth
20th December 1858

My dear Anne

I have sent you a few violets which I have just gathered, and hope they will not lose their sweet scent before they reach you.
Perhaps you have not seen the letter which Reverend Berridge left at Everton[sic] vicarage for …. Reverend Walter Shirley who supplic his place during his absence in London, so I copy in part that you may see how sumptuously that good man fared.  I hope however you will soon be able to live like Mrs Shirley upon mountain and port.  We shall be very glad to hear that you are gaining strength and with our …kindest love
Believe me my dear Anne
Your affectionate cousin
Esther Sharp
I have only written you a short letter because as you are weak I must not tire you.
Family prayers at 9 in the morning and 9 in the evening first reading a chapter and sing a Hymn, the hymn always I sign standing.  On Saturday evenings the serious people of the place come to my house about 7.  I first sing a hymn then expound a chapter then sing another hymn then pray, and conclude with singing on my knees, 'we …God from etc - dicet' You must eat what is set before you and be thankful.  I get hot rituals but once a week for myself, big on Saturday; but because you are an Honourable man I have ordered two hot joints be to got each week for you, with a pudding each day at noon, some pies and cold ham so that you will fare bravely; much better than your Master with barley head and dry fish.  There is also ale, port, mountain, and a little Madeira to drink, the liquor suits a coronet.  Use what I have just your own.  I make no feats but have all I can, to give all I can.  I have never yet been worth a groat at the years end, nor desire it.  I hoe you will like your expedition; the people are simple hearted, they want … and not venison[?], and can east their meat without sauce or a french cook.
The week day preachings are in the … at ½ past 6, if you can preach in a house, the method is first sing a hymn, then pray, then preach, then sing, then pray again, then conclude with 'Praise God from ….etc'
The lord bless you and make your journey prosperous
Your affectionate servant,
JB
fields.public_access_description:
This letter is part of a scant extant correspondence in the museum collection, between Anne Hale and her family over a period of 5 years.  Miss Hale lived in Brixton on the Angell Estate in a newly built terrace house with what appears to have been a large family.  The four letters and two receipts provide a small insight into the life of Anne Hale and her relations during the period of Miss Hale's move from her teenage years into adulthood. 
This particular letter is to Anne Hale from her cousin, Esther Sharp, wishing her well and providing some family news.
